lessons.title: Hello, World!
lessons.objective: Learn to display text on screen using the PRINT statement

content.introduction: Welcome to Applesoft BASIC! The first thing every programmer learns is how to make the computer say "Hello, World!"
content.explanation: The PRINT statement is the most fundamental command in BASIC. It displays text or numbers on the screen. When you want to print text (called a "string"), you must enclose it in double quotes.
tips: Strings must be enclosed in double quotes
PRINT alone creates a blank line
The ] symbol is the BASIC prompt waiting for your command

exercise.prompt: Write a command that prints 'HELLO WORLD' to the screen.
instructions: Type the PRINT command followed by your message in quotes
hints: Remember to use double quotes around your text
The full command is: PRINT "HELLO WORLD"

lessons.title: Working with Variables
lessons.objective: Learn to store and retrieve data using variables

content.introduction: Variables are like labeled boxes where you can store information to use later. They're one of the most powerful features of programming.
content.explanation: In BASIC, you can store numbers or text in variables. Variable names are usually single letters (A, B, X, Y). For text (strings), add a dollar sign ($) to the name (A$, N$). Use LET to assign a value to a variable, though LET is optional.

examples.description: Store a number and print it

tips: Variable names can be one or two characters (A, X, A1, X9)
Add $ for string variables (text)
LET is optional - you can write X = 5 instead of LET X = 5
Variables remember their values until you change them or run NEW

exercise.prompt: Create a variable called X, assign it the value 42, and print it.
instructions: First line: create the variable and assign the value
Remember, you can omit LET if you want
hints: You need two commands: one to set X, one to print it

lessons.title: Getting User Input
lessons.objective: Learn to accept input from the user with the INPUT statement

content.introduction: Programs become much more interesting when they can interact with the user. The INPUT statement lets your program ask questions and receive answers.
content.explanation: INPUT waits for the user to type something and press ENTER. You can provide a prompt (a question or message) to tell the user what to enter. The response is stored in a variable you specify.

examples.description: Ask for a name and greet

tips: The ? is automatically shown when INPUT waits
Use a semicolon (;) after the prompt text
For text input, use a string variable (ending in $)
For numbers, use a regular variable

exercise.prompt: Create a program that asks for the user's name and prints a greeting.
instructions: Use INPUT to ask for a name (store it in N$)
Use PRINT to say HELLO followed by the name
When prompted, type any name and press ENTER
hints: Notice the space after HELLO in the quotes
The semicolon joins the text with the name

lessons.title: Making Decisions with IF
lessons.objective: Learn to make your programs respond to different conditions

content.introduction: Programs need to make decisions based on conditions. The IF...THEN statement lets your code take different actions depending on whether something is true or false.
content.explanation: IF checks a condition. If it's true, the THEN part executes. You can compare values using operators: = (equal), < (less than), > (greater than), <= (less or equal), >= (greater or equal), and <> (not equal).

examples.description: Check if a number is big

tips: IF needs THEN - they always go together
Use = for equals (not == like some languages)
Use <> for "not equal to"
In program mode, you can use GOTO after THEN

exercise.prompt: Create a variable N with the value 15. If N is greater than 10, print 'BIG'. Otherwise, print 'SMALL'.
instructions: Use IF to check if N > 10
You'll need two IF statements to handle both cases
hints: For a complete solution, add: IF N <= 10 THEN PRINT "SMALL"
Since N is 15, only BIG should print

lessons.title: Repeating with FOR...NEXT
lessons.objective: Learn to repeat actions using loops

content.introduction: Loops are one of programming's superpowers - they let you repeat actions without writing the same code over and over. The FOR...NEXT loop runs a block of code a specific number of times.
content.explanation: FOR creates a loop variable and sets its starting value. TO specifies the ending value. Each time through the loop, the variable increases by 1 (or by STEP amount if specified). NEXT marks the end of the loop and returns to FOR.
content.syntax:
FOR variable = start TO end
  commands
NEXT variable

examples.code:
FOR I = 1 TO 3
PRINT I
NEXT I

FOR X = 5 TO 10 STEP 2
PRINT X
NEXT X

FOR N = 10 TO 1 STEP -1
PRINT N
NEXT N

tips: The loop variable is often I, J, or K by convention
STEP is optional - default is 1
Use negative STEP to count backwards
The variable in NEXT should match the one in FOR
You can use the loop variable inside the loop

exercise.prompt: Use a FOR loop to print the numbers 1 through 5, each on its own line.
instructions: Create a FOR loop that counts from 1 to 5
Inside the loop, PRINT the loop variable
Don't forget NEXT at the end

lessons.title: Your First BASIC Program
lessons.objective: Combine all concepts into a complete program

content.introduction: Now it's time to put everything together! You've learned PRINT, variables, INPUT, IF, and loops. Let's combine these to create a real program that runs from start to finish.
content.explanation: Unlike immediate mode where each command runs right away, programs use line numbers. Line numbers tell BASIC what order to run commands. Type lines in any order - BASIC sorts them by number. Use RUN to execute your program from the lowest line number.
content.syntax:
10 FIRST COMMAND
20 SECOND COMMAND
30 THIRD COMMAND
RUN

examples.code:
10 FOR I = 1 TO 3
20 PRINT "BASIC!"
30 NEXT I
RUN

tips: Line numbers usually go by 10s (10, 20, 30) so you can insert lines later
Type LIST to see your program
Type NEW to erase your program and start fresh
Type RUN to execute your program
You can type lines in any order - BASIC sorts them

exercise.prompt: Create a mini calculator program that asks for two numbers and prints their sum.
instructions: Line 10: INPUT the first number into variable A
Line 20: INPUT the second number into variable B
When it runs, enter any two numbers
hints: When you see ?, type a number and press ENTER
